item.title: A Bosnian tale
item.description: As I may have mentioned, I am a huge fan of the Erasmus programme. It is just that I have so many amazing experiences that it drives me to search for more. Recently, I have been on a training in Banja Luka, Bosnia. It was my first time in Bosnia and I can easily say I would never forget it. I don’t know if it is Bosnian magic or just the rahat lokum, but that’s the reality!

item.title: Why having international friends is so cool
item.description: Nationality- the status of belonging to a particular nation. For me this was never important. As a person who is always trying to be open-minded and respectful, meeting people with different backgrounds has always been a pleasure. Here are some of the pros of having international friendships that I have experienced: 1. We teach each other. It is so cool that you can teach people about your countries and they can teach you about their own.

item.title: 5 useful travel hacks
item.description: Stay in hostels. This one is pretty obvious but it cannot be overstated just how much more wallet-friendly budget accommodation options like hostels are compared with hotels, resorts and rental homes. Not only are you getting lower prices (some hostel beds are literally just a couple of dollars per night), but youâ€™re getting the authentic backpacker atmosphere, and memories to last a lifetime. Souvenirs are overrated. Seriously! Instead of bringing back a suitcase full of touristy paraphernalia, why not focus on collecting memories and experiences instead of material things.

item.title: First things first
item.description: Hi there! Let me tell you something about myself :) I am a very curious person and in my opinion, everyone should be. That is how we discover, absorb and grow. I think that learning should be purposeful, enlightening and thought-provoking, which is why I recommend a combination of reading and travel. On this blog you can read about some of my experiences, but also advices about how to create your own without struggles.
